title: Next Steps
---

Congratulations on completing the practical! Here are some useful resources. 

## Stack Overflow & Forums

These communities are invaluable:

-   [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/) - Programming Q&A
-   [RStudio Community](https://community.rstudio.com/) - R-specific help


## For R

- [R for Data Science (2e)](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/) - Comprehensive free book by Hadley Wickham
- [RStudio Primers](https://posit.cloud/learn/primers) - Interactive tutorials
- [Swirl](https://swirlstats.com/) - Learn R programming interactively

## For Python

- [Python for Everybody](https://www.py4e.com/) - Free course by University of Michigan
- [Kaggle Learn](https://www.kaggle.com/learn) - Practical micro-courses
- [DataCamp](https://www.datacamp.com/) - First course free, student discounts available

**Statistics with R/Python:**

- [StatQuest](https://www.youtube.com/c/joshstarmer) - Excellent YouTube channel for statistics
- [Introduction to Statistical Learning](https://www.statlearning.com/) - Free book with R and Python code


## Build Your Portfolio

### Project Ideas

1. **Analyze local transport patterns** using open transport data
2. **Recreate published analyses** to learn techniques
4. **Contribute to open source** R or Python packages

### Share Your Work

- Create a [GitHub](https://github.com/) profile for your code
- Build a portfolio website with [Quarto](https://quarto.org/)
- Write blog posts about what you learn
- Share projects on social media (#RStats, #DataScience)

## Advanced Topics to Explore

Once you're comfortable with basics:

### Data Science Skills

- **Version Control**: Git and GitHub for collaboration
- **Reproducible Research**: R Markdown, Quarto, Jupyter notebooks

### Specialized Topics

- **Spatial Data Science**: Working with spatial data (check out [geocompx.org](https://geocompx.org/))
- **Machine Learning**: Supervised and unsupervised learning
- **Deep Learning**: Neural networks for complex patterns
- **Time Series Analysis**: For temporal data
- **Network Analysis**: For transport networks and relationships

There's a lot to learn, but you don't need to learn everything at once. Pick one area, get comfortable, then expand gradually.

The field of data science is constantly evolving. Stay curious, keep learning, and don't be afraid to experiment!
